ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The first half was focused on the readings of the book "Influence" and they had interesting lessons from experiements and marketing research
Theoretical and practical lessons relating to arguments, influence, rhetoric, and persuasion in our contemporary society.
I learned more about the ideas of argument and persuasion and familiarized myself with some writing on the topics.

This course gave me a list of practical lessons to be more persuasive and have better arguments. I am more focused, intentional, and concise in my arguments and have found ways to listen better to make them more productive.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: very discussion based
Weakness: half of the class is about US politics. All discussions lead to the same conclusion (people are polarized). Honestly this portion of the class discussion was severely monopolized by select individuals and was much less engaging to others.
The course material is interesting, but the seminars became lectures with some Q&A instead of discussions. Either need different readings or a different course format.

Strengths: The assignments were fun and different from typical essays, and stretched the way I think. The handouts Professor Wicks created were also very helpful and interesting.

Weaknesses: We could have done breakout activities more often. I think they were often productive ways to give people things to talk about during class discussion. I would recommend banning laptops during class discussion, except when given a specific activity involving internet search. I know sometimes students used their laptops to work on other tasks during class, which drew away from their engagement and the overall quality of the conversation.

The course drew from an array of different disciplines when trying to explain something about argument and persuasion. I feel it was a little light on quantitative social science research but overall it had theoretical and practical readings.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Meh... severely politics based after the first couple of weeks. If you find that interesting then yes but otherwise no
Yes! Very interesting content and very well-spoken professor.

I think the course is interesting enough to warrant taking it, and the assignments are different and good exercises to complete. I would want to see the format changed though to make the seminar more discussion-based.

Yes. This is an interesting class and one that I feel has subtly changed how I interact with people in arguments. When I say that, I do not mean that I now have a list of manipulative tricks to persuade people, but I do feel more focused in articulating my opinion and better able to reflect on how certain points might work better to convince different people based on their perspective.
Yes, it was unique in style and content and very much fit the residential college series format.
